questions.text: All of the following form the filtration membrane except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The filtration membrane in the renal glomerulus is composed of fenestrated capillary endothelium, the glomerular basement membrane, and the filtration slits formed by podocyte foot processes. Parietal epithelial cells line the Bowman's capsule, not the capillaries, and do not participate in the actual filtration barrier.

So, the Glomerular Filtration Barrier is formed by:

  1. Podocytes
  2. Fenestrated endothelium
  3. Glomerular basement membrane

Explanation of other options:

Capillary endothelial cells (Option A): Part of the fenestrated endothelium, which allows passage of plasma components but blocks cells.
The foot process of podocytes (Option C): Create filtration slits that are a key part of the filtration membrane.
Basement membrane (Option D): The glomerular basement membrane serves as the primary size and charge barrier for filtration.

Key Takeaways:

The filtration membrane excludes parietal epithelial cells.

It includes capillary endothelium, basement membrane, and podocyte foot processes.

choices.text: Component of the mononuclear phagocytic system

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the function of mesangial cells in the glomerulus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mesangial cells are specialized pericytes located between glomerular capillaries. They possess phagocytic activity and are considered part of the mononuclear phagocytic system, helping to clear debris and immune complexes from the glomerulus. They do not form the filtration barrier nor secrete renin under normal physiological conditions.

Explanation of other options:

Formation filtration barrier (Option B): This function is performed by fenestrated endothelium, basement membrane, and podocytes, not mesangial cells.

Secretion of renin (Option C): Juxtaglomerular cells, not mesangial cells, secrete renin.

Explanation :

The illustrated cell has a large, centrally placed nucleus, pale cytoplasm, and distinct cell borders, features characteristic of principal cells of the collecting duct. These cells have few organelles and a smooth apical surface without brush borders, distinguishing them from cells in the proximal tubule or loop of Henle.

Different cells in Tubules of nephron are:


Explanation of other options:

Proximal convoluted tubule (Option A): Lined by cuboidal cells with a brush border and eosinophilic cytoplasm, indicating many mitochondria, not seen here.

Loop of Henle (Option B): Has simple squamous epithelium in thin segments or cuboidal with fewer organelles in thick segments, not this morphology.

Distal convoluted tubule (Option C): It also has cuboidal cells, but with no brush border, more mitochondria, and smaller, more densely packed cells that are less distinct than those of collecting duct cells.

questions.text: Which function is associated with the I cells (intercalated cells) in the epithelium of the collecting duct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Intercalated cells (I cells) in the collecting duct epithelium are primarily involved in acid-base regulation.

Type A intercalated cells secrete H+ions into the tubular lumen and reabsorb HCO₃-, while Type B intercalated cells perform the reverse. These cells contain carbonic anhydrase and specialized ion transporters for this function.

Explanation of other options:

Na+ reabsorption (Option B): This is mediated by principal cells, not I cells.

Water reabsorption influenced by vasopressin (Option C): Also a function of principal cells via aquaporin-2 channels.

Key Takeaways:

  • I cells regulate acid-base balance, not sodium or water handling.
  • Principal cells handle Na⁺ and H₂O reabsorption in the collecting duct.

questions.text: The capillaries around the tubules in the juxtra-medullary nephrons are known as
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The vasa recta are specialized straight capillaries that surround the loop of Henle in juxtamedullary nephrons. They play a crucial role in maintaining the medullary osmotic gradient by participating in countercurrent exchange, allowing for the concentration of urine.

Explanation of other options:

Glomerular capillaries (Option A): These are located in the renal corpuscle and are responsible for filtration, not tubular supply.

Peritubular capillaries (Option B): These surround cortical nephron tubules, not those of juxtamedullary nephrons.

Key Takeaways:

  • Vasa recta surrounds loops of Henle in juxtamedullary nephrons.
  • They maintain the medullary concentration gradient via countercurrent exchange.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of cortical nephrons?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cortical nephrons:
    • Make up 85% of total nephrons
    • Have short loops of Henle that extend only slightly into the medulla
    • They are primarily involved in filtration and excretion of waste products
    • They are not responsible for the formation of concentrated urine
  • Juxtamedullary nephrons, with long loops of Henle, are the main contributors to concentrated urine via the countercurrent mechanism

Table: Differences between Cortical and Juxtamedullary Nephrons

Explanation of other options:

Option A: Cortical nephrons are responsible for most filtration and urine formation (Option A ruled out)

Option B: They do have short loops of Henle (Option B ruled out)

Option D: They constitute ~85% of all nephrons (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Cortical nephrons are essential for filtration and waste removal
  • Juxtamedullary nephrons regulate urine concentration
  • Loop of Henle length is key to nephron function distinction

questions.text: The purpose of tubulo-glomerular feedback is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tubulo-glomerular feedback (TGF) is a mechanism that allows the glomerulus to adjust its filtration rate (GFR) based on signals from the distal tubule, particularly the macula densa.

When increased NaCl is detected in the distal tubule, the macula densa signals afferent arteriolar constriction, reducing GFR. This helps maintain a stable GFR despite fluctuations in systemic blood pressure.

Explanation of other options:

Regulation of plasma volume (Option B): An indirect consequence but not the primary role of TGF.


Regulation of Na+ in plasma (Option C): TGF responds to NaCl levels in the filtrate, but does not directly regulate plasma Na+.

Regulation of renin secretion (Option D): Renin secretion is influenced by macula densa but through a separate mechanism, not the main purpose of TGF.

Key Takeaways:

  • Tubulo-glomerular feedback helps maintain stable GFR.
  • It involves macula densa sensing NaCl and modulating afferent arteriole tone.

questions.text: PAH (para amino hippuric acid) is useful to measure which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Para-aminohippuric acid (PAH) is both freely filtered at the glomerulus and actively secreted by the proximal tubule, allowing nearly all PAH entering the kidney via plasma to be excreted in the urine. Since it is almost completely cleared from the renal plasma in a single pass, PAH clearance approximates renal plasma flow (RPF) under low plasma concentrations.


Explanation of other options:

Glomerular filtration rate (Option B): Measured by inulin clearance, not PAH.

Excretion rate (Option C): PAH's excretion rate reflects secretion and filtration, but does not directly measure them.

Key Takeaways:

  • PAH clearance ≈ : Renal plasma flow due to near-complete renal extraction.
  • Inulin is the gold standard for GFR

questions.text: Which of the following is not a factor to calculate the clearance of substance?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:
Clearance of a substance is calculated using the formula:

C = (U × V) / P

U: urine concentration of the substance
V: urine flow rate
P: plasma concentration of the substance

The concentration in the filtrate is not directly measured or used because it is generally assumed to be equal to the plasma concentration for freely filtered substances and does not affect the clearance formula. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following substances causes renal vasodilation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dopamine is synthesized in the kidney and acts on D1 receptors to produce renal vasodilation and natriuresis, thereby increasing renal blood flow and potentially GFR, especially via afferent arteriolar dilation.

Acetylcholine and prostaglandins also cause vasodilation.

Explanation of other options:

Norepinephrine (Option A): Causes renal vasoconstriction, particularly of afferent arterioles and interlobular arteries, mediated by α1-adrenergic receptors (and less so by α2), generally reducing renal blood flow and GFR.

Angiotensin II (Option C): Exerts vasoconstrictor effects on both afferent and efferent arterioles, with a stronger effect on the efferent arteriole, which may help maintain or slightly increase GFR in low doses but reduces renal perfusion overall.

Key Takeaways:

  • Dopamine increases renal blood flow and GFR through vasodilation.
  • NE and Ang II cause vasoconstriction, limiting renal perfusion.
  • Selective afferent dilation raises GFR, while constriction reduces it.

Angiotensin II increases thirst by acting on the hypothalamic thirst center to stimulate water intake.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male was admitted for management of hypertension. Shortly after starting an antihypertensive medication, he developed signs of acute renal failure. Which class of antihypertensive drug is most likely responsible for this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • ACE inhibitors can cause acute renal failure in susceptible individuals, especially in the elderly or those with bilateral renal artery stenosis, volume depletion, or pre-existing kidney disease.
  • They reduce angiotensin II levels, leading to dilation of efferent arterioles, which can significantly decrease glomerular filtration pressure, resulting in renal failure.

Explanation of other options:

Diuretics (Option A): May cause volume depletion and electrolyte imbalance, but are less likely to cause direct renal failure unless overdosed or in combination with other nephrotoxic agents.

Calcium channel blockers (Option B): Do not significantly impair renal hemodynamics; generally safe in renal disease.

Beta blockers (Option C): Typically do not cause renal failure; they reduce cardiac output but not to the extent of altering renal perfusion drastically in most patients.

Key Takeaways:

  • ACE inhibitors can precipitate acute kidney injury in at-risk patients.
  • Efferent arteriole dilation lowers glomerular filtration pressure.
  • Caution in elderly and renal artery stenosis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient visited the physician for urinary problems. The doctor decided to calculate the GFR in this patient. The patient's urine flow rate is 0.8 ml/min, Concentration of inulin measured in urine is 30 mg/ml, Plasma concentration of inulin is 0.3 mg/ml. What is the GFR in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) is calculated using the formula:

GFR = (U × V) / P

Where:
U = Urine concentration of inulin = 30 mg/ml
V = Urine flow rate = 0.8 ml/min
P = Plasma concentration of inulin = 0.3 mg/ml

So, GFR = (30 × 0.8) / 0.3 = 24 / 0.3 = 80 ml/min

Key Takeaways:

  • Use GFR = (U × V) / P for inulin.
  • Inulin is ideal for GFR as it is freely filtered and neither reabsorbed nor secreted.

questions.text: Which of the following factors reduces the glomerular filtration rate by reducing the hydrostatic pressure in the plasma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Reduced systemic blood pressure lowers the renal perfusion pressure, resulting in a drop in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure, which directly reduces GFR. The glomerular hydrostatic pressure is the main driving force for filtration, and any systemic drop can significantly impair it if not compensated.

Other factors affecting GFR:

  • Exercise: GFR decreases due to sympathetic stimulation, which causes more afferent arteriolar constriction than
  • Pregnancy: GFR increases because of increased blood volume (BV), cardiac output (CO), and decreased renal vascular resistance, leading to increased renal blood flow (RBF).
  • Posture:
    • Standing for a long time: GFR decreases due to sympathetic stimulation and pooling of blood in the veins of the lower limbs and abdomen.
    • Supine position: GFR is increased.
  • Sleep: GFR is less due to decreased circulatory activity.
  • Weather:
    • More GFR in the rainy season
    • Less GFR in summer due to decreased extracellular fluid (ECF) volume; in winter and the rainy season, water loss is less.
  • Gender: GFR is lower in females than in males.
  • Age: GFR is decreased in the elderly due to functional loss of nephrons.
  • Diet: A protein-rich diet increases GFR.

Explanation of other options:

Constriction of efferent arterioles (Option A): Initially increases glomerular hydrostatic pressure, thereby increasing GFR.


Edema of the kidney (Option C): May raise interstitial pressure, possibly affecting GFR, but not via reduced hydrostatic pressure in plasma.


Hyperproteinemia (Option D): Increases plasma oncotic pressure, which opposes filtration, not hydrostatic pressure.

Key Takeaways:

  • Systemic BP directly affects glomerular hydrostatic pressure and GFR.
  • GFR declines with reduced perfusion pressure unless autoregulation compensates.
